lobby.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a wide passage or large hall just inside the entrance to a public building
lobby.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I’ll meet you in the entrance lobby.
lobby.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a hall in the British parliament where members of parliament and the public meet
lobby.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: one of the two passages in the British parliament where members go to vote for or against a bill
lobby.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a group of people who try to persuade a government that a particular law or situation should be changed
lobby.translation[0].definitions[3].note: In this meaning, lobby is usually followed by a singular verb
The business lobby has warned the government against raising taxes
The business lobby have warned the government against raising taxes
lobby.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: an attempt to persuade a government to change a law, make a new law etc
lobby.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: a mass lobby of Parliament by women’s organizations
lobby.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to try to persuade the government or someone with political power that a law or situation should be changed
lobby.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The group is lobbying for a reduction in defence spending.
We’ve been lobbying our state representative to support the new health plan.
lobby.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a group of people with similar interests who try to persuade a government that a particular law or situation should be changed
lobby.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Opposition to the new law is expected from India’s industry lobby.
The Prime Minister is still under pressure from the farm lobby.
lobby.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: an attempt by a group of people to persuade members of a government that a particular law or situation should be changed
lobby.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: A mass lobby of parliament is planned for next week.
lobby.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to try to persuade a government that a particular law or situation should be changed
lobby.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The financial community is expected to continue lobbying Congress to introduce new legislation.
Industrialists are already lobbying against the reforms.
Small firms are lobbying for a change to the law.
